question: You know the problem with Hollywood? They make shit. Unbelievable, unremarkable shit. I'm not some grungy filmmaker- wannabee searching for existentialism through a haze of bong-smoke. It's easy to pick apart bad acting, short-sighted directing, or the purely moronic stringing together of words many of the studios term as prose. No, I'm talking the lack of realism. Realism. Not a pervasive element in the modern American cinematic vision. Take Dog Day Afternoon for example. Arguably Pacino's greatest performance, excepting The Godfather, Part I, and Scarface, of course. A masterpiece of directing, easily Lumet's best. The acting, the script, cinematography, all top notch. But, they didn't push the envelope. What if in Dog Day, Sonny really wanted to get away with it? What if, and here's where it gets tricky. What if they'd started killing hostages? No mercy, no quarter, meet our demands or the cute blonde in the bell bottoms gets one in the back of the head, bam, splatter. What? Still no bus? How many innocent victims would they let get sprayed across the windows before the city reversed its policy on hostage situations? And this was 1976. No C.N.N., no C.N.B.C., no M.T.V. No Internet. Fast forward to the present, same situation. Can you imagine the feeding frenzy of the modern media? In hours it would be the top story from Boston to Budapest. All caught in 150 millimeter zoom, computer enhanced, and color corrected. You would practically taste the brain matter. Six hostages die. Ten. Twelve. Twenty. Thirty. Relentless. One after another. All over a bus, a plane, and a couple of million dollars that were federally insured. Just a thought. I mean it's not really within the realm of conventional cinema, but what if...?
answer: You know, this movie of yours, I don't think it would have worked.

question: Really? How come?
answer: Audiences love happy endings.

question: Pacino escapes. With the money. Boyfriend gets the sex change operation. They live happily ever after. No?
answer: No.

question: Homophobia?
answer: Bad guy can't win. It's a morality tale. One way or the other, he's gotta go down.

question: Is everyone in position?
answer: What are you doing?

question: Get her at your first opportunity.
answer: I've seen what this man is capable of --

question: This better be important, you pulled me out of session.
answer: Senator, I wouldn't have asked you to come here if it wasn't. Senator, we just received a communication that Axl Torvalds was intercepted entering the continental U.S.

question: When?
answer: Within the last two hours. According to our source inside the F.B.I., he was nabbed coming through customs at L.A.X. Alone...

question: Do they know who they are dealing with?
answer: It is unlikely, sir. It was a routine check and Torvalds freaked out. They just got lucky.

question: This ain't good, boys. The Vortex has used Torvalds before. What do the feds know?
answer: Nothing as of yet. He's refusing to speak English and the Finnish consulate has already contacted the State Department...

question: So we haven't been compromised?
answer: We're not sure. We're working on that right now.

question: You better get sure real quick, son, 'cause someone's cock's liable to end up on the block on this one. And I promise you it won't be mine.
answer: Senator, I think we'll be okay here --

question: I don't fucking pay you to think, Kaplan. I pay you to keep me informed. I know the Vortex. That's why I voted against using him on American soil. It's like using the Ebola virus to cure a cancer patient. Son, what do you think's going to happen if he starts tying up loose ends.
answer: Yessir. I understand.

question: Who are you supposed to be?
answer: Hello, Stanley. I'm Ginger.

question: Is that right?
answer: For someone the N.S.A. has listed as the most dangerous hacker in America, you sure don't look like much. Don't look so surprised. I know everything there is to know about you, Stan. From your mom's maiden name to how big your... Bank account is.

question: How'd you get past my dog?
answer: Boys like me.

question: Great. What are you selling again?
answer: Did I say I was selling something? I'm here to help you, Stan. Look at you, you're a mess. My employer wants to meet you. You're not very good at this, are you?

question: You're fucking up my chi.
answer: Can I see that? You need to straighten your left arm. You're bending it. Trust me. This is not a nice place you have here, Stanley. I've only been here a few minutes and I'm already starting to feel sorry for myself.

question: You're wasting your time. I even touch a computer, I go straight to Leavenworth, do not pass go, do not collect 200 dollars. Whatever I was...
answer: Stanley, think about it, they still teach your techniques at I'm not here to suck your dick, Stanley, you can sit around doing the martyr thing as long as you like. He'll pay you just to meet you.

question: I gotta go to work.
answer: Oh that's right, and fine work it is, too. Stanley... Have you spoken to Holly lately? Shit...

question: Hello.
answer: Melissa... Holly home?

question: Stanley. Why are you calling here?
answer: I want to talk with Holly.

question: It's... It's twelve-thirty, Stanley. She's in school. You know it's illegal for you to talk to her.
answer: Don't do this, Mel. It's not good for Holly --

question: How the hell would you know what is or isn't good for my daughter? You've spent the last two years in prison.
answer: Mel --

question: Stop calling me that, Stanley.
answer: I just want to see my baby.

question: Well, she doesn't want to see you, Stanley, and I swear to fucking God, if you contact her, I'll have Larry's attorney throw you into a hole so deep and dark it'll make Leavenworth seem like two weeks in Vegas; during which I'll personally pay two ball-busting skin-heads to --
answer: Wow, Mel, you can take the girl out of the trailer park, but you can't take the trailer park out of the girl.

question: I will not let myself be manipulated by you, Stanley. Larry's her father now.
answer: Larry's the porn king --

question: Larry's a film financier, a good husband, and an astute businessman. What films he's involved in are a function of profitability and none of your business. Get help, Stanley, get into a program, get a therapist, get a dog, but whatever you do, stay away from my child.
answer: Your child? She's our child.

question: She will never be your child. You'll never have the kind of money to match Larry's lawyers in court. Forget Holly.
answer: What are you doing here? Judas.

question: What are you doing here? Judas.
answer: Hello, Stanley.

question: Look, I'm beginning to lose my sense of humor about --
answer: Let's cut through the bullshit, Stan. If you ever want to have a chance in hell of getting your daughter back you'll shut up and listen. Unless of course you want to stay here in your pathetic, loser life while she learns what it's like to be a fluffer in one of her new daddy's videos.

question: Do me the courtesy of not confusing your own childhood with my daughter's.
answer: Look at your situation, Stanley. For twenty months you've been in court six times, each time your custody case has been thrown out. Your situation doesn't look good, sweetheart. How much would it cost to retain the best family lawyer in the country and regain custody of your daughter?

question: All the way through the jury trial?
answer: Yeah.

question: A lot.
answer: This should get you started. Whattaya have to lose? Just meet him. One time. That's it. You don't like the setup, walk away.

question: That's it?
answer: That's it. And you keep the money.

question: You've fucked up now, Hamlet.
answer: And Michaels.

question: Yessir.
answer: Hamlet was a Dane.

question: Adane?
answer: Forget it. Why would the number one cracker in the world risk life imprisonment to enter the continental U.S.?

question: Forget it. Why would the number one cracker in the world risk life imprisonment to enter the continental U.S.?
answer: My client has repeatedly reserved his right not answer any questions at this time. He told me to tell Mister Roberts that he is quite fond of 'The X-Files.'

question: You need another cup of coffee --
answer: Goddammit!

question: Until a year ago I was head of the largest task force on cyber- criminals in the entire world. But, I burned out. It happens. I snapped. I shot a suspect in the fucking hand. Accident. Do you know how hard it is to work a keyboard with one hand?
answer: Whatever you can do to me, he can do worse. I'm already dead. The only place I stand a chance is back in my country. I have friends there.

question: I tell you what, you tell me what I want to know and I guarantee you'll be on the next flight to Finland. First class. Courtesy of the U.S. Government.
answer: I'll tell you what I know.

question: Who is he?
answer: He exists in a world beyond your world. What we only fantasize, he does. He lives a life where nothing is beyond him. But it is all an act. For all his charisma and charm. For all his wealth and expensive toys. Beneath it all he is a driven, unflinching, calculating machine, who takes what he wants, when he wants, then disappears -- -- It works like this. I fly to where I am to meet him. He sends one of his people to meet me. He tells me what he needs. I do my job, I'm paid. And I leave.

question: That's a real nice story. But you haven't given me shit.
answer: Excuse me, sir... you have a call.

question: So, take a message.
answer: It's Assistant Director Joy, he said it's important.

question: Shut up. This is Roberts, I have a call from A.D. Joy.
answer: Joy.

question: Roberts. You needed me.
answer: What do you mean?

question: You didn't call me?
answer: You just called me...

question: I wish you'd let me buy you a suit.
answer: I'm happy with what I'm wearing.

question: You have no self-esteem, Stanley.
answer: I know.

question: Big Stan. Nice suit.
answer: Thanks.

question: You know, they say it's the clothes that make the man...
answer: You buy it?

question: Hope not. Buy you a drink?
answer: I flew fifteen hundred miles for this meeting, how 'bout we get to the point.

question: Actually you flew 1500 miles for 100 grand. But that's not the point. I heard this story about this young hacker who made a virus that broke the F.B.I.'s Carnivore program that was actively reading every subscriber's E-mail and scrambled the systems. He did what the federal judges wouldn't do and kept the government out of our Privacy.
answer: I think I heard that. Story is he went to jail and the federal Carnivore program is back in full swing. It was a real tragedy. What can I do for you?

question: Stanley, meet Helga.
answer: Look, I don't have a lot of patience for this --

question: Stanley, we have a problem, maybe you can help us out. Take a look at this.
answer: You know I can't touch that.

question: No need for modesty, we're all friends here, Stanley.
answer: This is bullshit. I came --

question: You want something from me, amigo, I want something from you. D.O.D. dBase, 128 bit R.S.A. encryption. Whattaya think? Impossible?
answer: Nothing's impossible.

question: So it can be done? Maybe slide in a Trojan horse hiding a worm?
answer: Something like that. Is this an interview?

question: Sort of. Marco, let's give him some incentive.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Relax, Stanley. I've been told the best crackers in the world could do this in sixty minutes. Unfortunately, I need someone who can do it in sixty seconds.
answer: You're kidding...

question: 'Fraid not. Forty-five seconds. Time is a wasting, big guy. You have thirty seconds, Stanley. She's very good, isn't she, Stanley? C'mon, Stanley. 20 seconds. Fifteen. Ten... Nine... Three... Two... Too bad, Stanley. Ya gotta die.
answer: Wait... !

question: I was just fucking with you, Stan.
answer: So was I.

question: Shit! What are you looking at?
answer: Relax, Stanley. You can do this.

question: Get away from me.
answer: I want to help you.

question: Help? Help what, squeegee my brain off the ceiling?
answer: It was just a test, Stan, you passed.

question: A test... I don't know why I let you talk me into this. I can't believe how desperate I am.
answer: I thought you were here saving your daughter, Stanley.

question: Look... I'd do anything to get Holly back. But, if I end up in a box or back in jail, then I really can't help her, can I? What I should do, is take my money and go back to court.
answer: Back to court? Back to Melissa's gladiators? You throw a hundred grand at her, she'll throw five back at you. It's not about Holly, it's about beating you. You know that. Think, Stanley.

question: What I'm thinking about is that you're willing to put a gun to my head to see if I can hack --
answer: Sorry... So, let me sum it up for you, Stanley. You live in a trailer. You're a felon, working a dead- end job. You want to get Holly back, Gabriel's your only shot.

question: Tell me you have some good news for me.
answer: Actually we have a small ray of hope in the vast darkness that is your life, sir. Check this out. See these two guys? Now watch this... Recognize those two, same guys, next day. Question is -- -- who's that?

question: Stanley Jobson...
answer: Wired's man of the year, 1996. Pretty much a burnout but he was the hacker zeitgeist of his day --

question: I know who Jobson is. I busted him. Why are you in L.A.?
answer: His ex-wife lives in Malibu.

question: You definitely have a gift, Stan. The most powerful people on the planet are like you. With a laptop and a phone line you can make God look like a thirteen-year-old with a stack of Playboys and a lack of imagination. C'mere, Stan, let me show you something. Pretty impressive, huh. So...
answer: So?

question: Here's the deal. I need a worm, Stanley. A hydra, actually. A multi-headed worm to break an encryption and then sniff out latent digital footprints throughout an encrypted network.
answer: What kind of cypher?

question: Vernam encryption.
answer: A Vernam's impossible. Its key code is destroyed upon implementation. Not to mention being a true 128 bit encryption.

question: Actually, we're talking 512 bit.
answer: It's impossible.

question: Tell ya what, I'll pay you ten million dollars. That should be enough to get your daughter back... ... unless of course it's impossible.
answer: Nothing's impossible. What?

question: Nothing's impossible. What?
answer: C'mon, Stan. Let's get to work. It won't bite you, I promise.

question: I don't know. It's gonna be pretty hard without a gun to my head.
answer: Well, let's put a gun to your head. Tell me about your worm, Stanley. You surprised that a girl with real breasts and an I.Q. over 70 can give you a hard-on?

question: I thought you were Gabriel's.
answer: I am not what you think I am. You're a smart guy, Stanley. You figure me out. Don't you have that just-fucked- the-neighbor's-cat look this morning. Problem?

question: Pretty impressive.
answer: I thought we went over all that last night.

question: The book, Ginger.
answer: Ohhh. Look, no pictures. Get out of my light.

question: Can I borrow your car? There's something I need to do.
answer: If you're going to see your daughter, you might want to reevaluate the way you look. Just a thought.

question: Look, creep, I don't think so -- Daddy? Daddy!
answer: Hey, sweetheart.

question: Daddy... What are you doing here? I missed you so much.
answer: Me too, baby. I brought you something.

question: Oh, Daddy. If Mom finds out you're here she's gonna have you thrown back in jail.
answer: It's okay, baby. Let me give you a ride home. C'mon. You believe in me, right?

question: Of course, but --
answer: I've found a way to get you back, sweetheart. It's my one shot and I'm taking it. Just give me a couple of days.

question: I don't want anything else to happen to you, Dad.
answer: Holly, everything's going to be okay. You just have to trust me.

question: I love you, Daddy.
answer: Who the fuck are you? Shit... Yep.

question: Fuck this. Go get him. What are you doing in L.A., Stan?
answer: Vacationing...

question: Why were you running? We just wanted to talk.
answer: Are you arresting me?

question: For violating your parole by leaving Texas without permission or for evading a federal agent and almost getting me killed in the process? No, I'm not.
answer: Then why are we talking?

question: Didn't know the court lifted the sanction preventing you from seeing your daughter.
answer: Fuck you.

question: You just want to cut through the pleasantries and get down to business? Fine. I can help you with your daughter, Stan. Help me, I'll help you.
answer: You'll have to forgive me, the fact that you put me in jail for 18 months doesn't inspire a lot of trust.

question: Whether I agreed with what you did or not, you broke the law, Stanley.
answer: I guess we were both doing what we had to. This was a nice trip down memory lane, but if you're not arresting me...

question: So, why was it you are in L.A. again?
answer: I told you --

question: -- vacationing. That's right. Ya know it's funny. Axl Torvalds was just here for a vacation, too. Isn't it odd that the two best hackers in the world are here at the same time.
answer: I'm a sucker for Disneyland. Tell Torvalds I said hello.

question: If you're not careful you can tell him yourself. He's dead. Give him a card. In case you think of anything else you want to tell me.
answer: Sorry about your nose.

question: Hey, Stan. You know, you're in way over your head here.
answer: I know.

question: It's a long walk back up the hill, Stanley. You want us to give you a lift? Follow him.
answer: I have to hand it to you, Ginger. You look good wearing anything. Even a wire. You gonna kill me?

question: I have to hand it to you, Ginger. You look good wearing anything. Even a wire. You gonna kill me?
answer: I'm thinking. What are you doing here, Stanley?

question: I should probably ask you the same question.
answer: What happened to you?

question: Little accident. Sorry about your car. I've had a pretty shitty day so far. Looks like it just got worse. Who are you, Ginger?
answer: I can't tell you.

question: You can't tell me? Well, that's just fuckin' peachy.
answer: Think, Stanley.

question: Who are you?
answer: He'll kill me.

question: That's not my problem, is it? You're asking for a lot of faith here, Ging, without givin' me any. You --
answer: -- Stanley --

question: -- brought me into this mess --
answer: -- Stanley --

question: -- I deserve to know who's playing me, Ginger. Who the fuck are you?
answer: I'm D.E.A., Stanley.

question: Actually... Thought maybe you'd like to see me get you your hydra.
answer: Get?

question: C'mon.
answer: You look like shit. Ginger kick your ass?

question: Yes he is. I see you have a groupie.
answer: You know, it'd be a lot simpler if you would tell me exactly what the hydra is going to be used for?

question: Have you heard of Operation Swordfish?
answer: Nope.

question: You'll appreciate the irony here -- -- In the early Eighties the D.E.A. set up a network of dummy corporations as a government front to launder drug money and gather evidence. Problem is, the front companies started making money. Lots of money. By 1986, when Operation Swordfish was terminated, there was close to 400 million dollars in the D.E.A.'s accounts.
answer: Money that just sorta disappeared.

question: It didn't disappear. It just sat in those accounts earning interest, it's been 15 years. You have any concept how much money we'd be actually talking about today? Billions, brother. That's nine zeros. Look, this is a sweet deal. We go in over phone lines. Pop the firewall, drop in the hydra, and just sit back and wait for the money.
answer: Before we can tap into the secure cluster, you have to find one of the banks on the backbone of this network. Do you know how many banks there are in the U.S.? It could take years.

question: We have him yet? We have a problem -- -- Seems you have gotten yourself in a predicament.
answer: I'm not exactly following you.

question: Transfer the pictures.
answer: Senator, I sincerely hope you did not contact me and jeopardize the safety of me and my men for this.

question: Goddamn right I did. You know where I got that? From the deputy director of the F.B.I. He thought I might be interested.
answer: Sir, with all due respect. Do you think there is any aspect of this operation I am not fully aware of?

question: We are aborting the operation and securing alternative means of finance elsewhere.
answer: What?

question: We are aborting this operation. Take a vacation.
answer: A vacation? Have I ever failed you, sir?

question: That's not the point.
answer: It's my point. Senator, this operation is going forward.

question: You understand what you are saying?
answer: Everything is under control.

question: Fuck!! Jesus Christ!
answer: Stan? What's wrong, Stanley, you look like you've seen a ghost? C'mon, Stanley. Let's talk.

question: Okay...
answer: Let's go.

question: Why can't we talk here?
answer: 'Cause I don't want to talk to you in the house, Stanley. Let's go. How you doing, Stanley?

question: Fine.
answer: Something you need to say to me?

question: What the hell is going on here?
answer: You know anything about Harry Houdini? He used to make an elephant disappear in a theater full of people. You know how he did it?

question: How?
answer: Misdirection.

question: What are you doing?
answer: We have a tail. Hope you had a light lunch, Stan. Hold the wheel.

question: Shit, it's blocked.
answer: Keep it straight. It's just rough when you grow up lovin' James Bond movies. Don't worry, Stanley, it'll be over soon. Drive, drive! Go, go!

question: I am! Shit!
answer: Keep your cool, Stanley. Goddamit. I knew it. Get in the fucking car, Stanley.

question: I'm not going anywhere until you tell me what's going on.
answer: You're on my good side and you want to stay there. Stanley, I like you, but don't confuse kindness with weakness. So, get in the fuckin' car. I need my hydra.

question: Stanley? You alright?
answer: What do you think? I just watched that maniac murder ten men in the street. I'm just fucking great. It doesn't matter if I get my daughter back if I'm dead. Even if I do survive this, who's gonna keep me out of jail? You?

question: I won't let anything happen to you, Stanley. You have to trust me.
answer: Trust you? Two hours ago I found out you're D.E.A. The feds are crawling up my ass and there's a dead body in the basement that looks just like Gabriel.

question: Stanley, if we don't find out who he's working for then we're just going to have to do this all over again.
answer: Your little slush fund is not my problem. I'm pulling the plug on this rodeo. Roberts may be an asshole, but he is definitely the lesser of the two evils.

question: I've been working on this thing for eight months, and I will not let some jarhead fed fuck up my operation. Please, I know what I'm doing. C'mon, Stanley. You have twelve hours. Do what he wants. Finish the worm.
answer: You're starting to sound just like him.

question: Ahh, the great American outdoors. I'll never understand the appeal of fly-fishing, Jim. A little too much like masturbation for me, without the payoff. This's a catch-and-release stream, isn't it?
answer: That's right.

question: Oh c'mon, Jim. You gotta see the irony in the chairman of the Joint Sub-Committee on Crime, fishing in a catch-and-release stream. How could you do it, Jim? After all we have sacrificed. All the blood, all the death... I've changed my identity so many times, I don't even know what I look like anymore. How could you turn on me when we are so close?
answer: You did this to yourself.

question: You brought me in to get the job done and you didn't want to know about the consequences.
answer: The F.B.I. was watching you --

question: I told you there was nothing that I was unaware of --
answer: That's why we're here. You are too arrogant, too aggressive --

question: You have misplaced your loyalties, Senator. You have sold America out. I am a patriot, and patriotism does not have a four-year shelf life. Unfortunately, politicians do.
answer: And what are you going to do with that?

question: Make sure that bus doesn't top out over fifteen-seven. Stan, how are you?
answer: Fine.

question: Have you finished? Here.
answer: What? Hello. Why?

question: Just like I promised, Stanley.
answer: Then let me go. I want to see my daughter.

question: Soon, Stanley. Walk with me. I'm about to do something against my better judgement. I'm going to tell you something I never tell anyone. I'm going to tell you who I am.
answer: Don't bother. I know who you are.

question: Do you? You think I'm a bank robber. Really, I'm just like you.
answer: Like me? You're a murderer.

question: That I am. And worse. Much worse. I am forced to operate on a different plane than you. But, I have ethics. Rules to which I must adhere. 200 years ago Thomas Jefferson wrote a letter to Madison because he was concerned that the freedoms of the constitution would be ignored.
answer: I don't understand why the fuck you're telling me this.

question: Listen to me and you will. In the 1950s, armed with this letter, J. Edgar Hoover created an organization to protect the freedoms of this country at all costs.
answer: I don't care about any of this. All I care about is my daughter.

question: I'm talking about your daughter.
answer: My daughter...

question: Yes. You, your daughter and 200 million other Americans who take their freedoms for granted. You don't understand what it takes to protect those freedoms. That's my job, Stanley, to protect your way of life at all costs.
answer: So you and your band of lunatics are really stealing all this money to protect me.

question: That's right, Stanley -- -- 'cause wars cost money.
answer: You're going into the fucking bank.

question: That's what I'm telling you, Stanley. We are at war.
answer: War? Who are we at war with?

question: Anyone who infringes on America's freedom. Terrorists' states, Stanley. Someone must take their war to them. They bomb a church, we bomb ten. They hijack a plane, we take out an airport. They execute American tourists, we tactically nuke an entire city. We must make terrorism so horrific that it becomes unthinkable to attack Americans.
answer: I'm out. I'm not doing this. You're insane.

question: I need the disk. Almost done. Whoa! What the hell just happened?
answer: They just cut the power. Forget it. How long to transfer the money?

question: Couple of minutes. Which accounts?
answer: National Bank of Zurich. Spread it evenly over these accounts. It won't be there that long.

question: Great.
answer: Good job, Stanley, I got someone who wants to see you.

question: Holly! Are you okay?
answer: Hold up. Told you I was a man of my word, Stanley.

question: Shit! Run, Holly!
answer: Get her!

question: Won't do you any good. The money jumps every 60 seconds from one numbered account to another and will for the next ten years. 'Course it wasn't supposed to happen for another six hours. The power surge must have scrambled the internal clock. But, you kill me and you never get a single dollar. You let the hostages go and then I'll tell you where and when you can extract the money. We all walk away, nobody gets hurt. The accounts are encrypted with a 1024 bit cipher. Even I can't break through the fire wall. It's my act of God policy. Deal?
answer: I'm thinking. Tell ya what. No deal. Marco! Grab Agent Sculley!

question: No, don't do this.
answer: In all reality, Stan, she has you to thank for this. That first night in Prague you broke the D.O.D. database that contained her true identity. She's D.E.A., Stan, but without you, I never would have known.

question: What are you doing? Stop!
answer: String up the D.E.A. bitch.

question: Just let her down. I'll do whatever you want.
answer: Then get me my money, Stan.

question: I'm not doing shit until you bring her down. I'm serious. Let her down. Now!
answer: Okay.

question: Nooo...
answer: Take a moment, big guy. Don't make me put you in a wheelchair.

question: You didn't have to kill her.
answer: I didn't Stan, you did. But we're not done yet. Marco... There are a lot of hostages here. I cared about Ginger, can you imagine what I could do to someone I don't care about. How long before the money jumps?

question: Sixty seconds.
answer: They better hope you installed a back door or it could be a long day. Somebody get me a laptop. Okay, Stan. Sixty seconds. Forty-five seconds, Stanley.

question: I need another laptop, logged on!
answer: Twenty seconds, Stan. Fifteen. She's gonna die, Stanley.

question: Shut up! C'mon, c'mon.
answer: Ten. Nine... Eight... Seven.

question: I need your account number.
answer: Four, three, two... One.

question: Let her go. Now, goddammit, it's done. Let her go!
answer: Well, that was fun. Well, 'bout time for us to leave.

question: They'll never let you escape. You've gone too far.
answer: Au contraire. Do you hear that? That's the sound of America watching. Let's roll.

question: I don't think any of us want a repeat of this morning. Keep at least a hundred yards from this bus at all times and I want the airspace for five miles clear. Ladies and gentlemen, we will be in your lives for approximately 55 more minutes. This bus has just become your new yard. So sit back, think happy thoughts, and this will be over before you can say 'cat in the hat.' Whaddaya think, Stanley?
answer: You'll never get away. Even if they have to kill everyone on the bus.

question: Really? Five hundred bucks says I do. Tell ya what, Stanley, I'll even spot you the five bills. Stan, c'mere. Take a look.
answer: How the fuck can you justify all this?

question: You're not looking at the big picture. Stanley, here's a scenario. You have the power to cure all of the world's diseases. But the price for this is that you must kill a single, innocent child. Could you kill that child to save the world?
answer: No.

question: You disappoint me, Stanley. It's the greatest good.
answer: How about ten innocents?

question: Now you're getting it. How about a hundred? How about a thousand? Not to save the world, but just to preserve our way of life.
answer: No man has the right to make that decision. You're no different than any other terrorist.

question: You're wrong, Stanley. Some men are put here to shape destiny, to protect freedom, despite the atrocities they must commit. I am one of those men. Thousands die every day for no reason at all, where is your bleeding heart for them? You give your twenty dollars to Greenpeace every year and think you are changing the world. What countries will harbor terrorists, when they realize the consequences of what I will do? Did you know I can buy nuclear warheads in Minsk for forty million each? I buy half a dozen, I even get a discount.
answer: What the fu --

question: I saw Sugarland Express, Stan. Didn't like the way it ended.
answer: I thought we were going to the airport.

question: I'm F.B.I...
answer: Are we sure this is Gabriel?

question: It sure looks like Gabriel Shear. What the hell was he doing in that bank?
answer: What about Ginger? You can't find her body?

question: Keep looking. Bodies just don't fucking disappear.
answer: Disappear...

question: I would like to transfer money between my employer's accounts.
answer: Certainly. May I have your employer's account number and password, please? Oh, of course. You realize, how should I say, there is a substantial amount of money in that account.

question: That's why I'm here. My employer doesn't like drawing attention to himself. He likes to keep a low profile.
answer: Of course. Would you feel more comfortable dealing with the bank president?

question: Would you?
answer: Yes...

question: Get him.
answer: Right away. A glass of Cristal while you... Wait a moment...

question: What?
answer: There seems to have been a series of large withdrawals out of this account.

question: Everything okay, Dad?
answer: Everything's fine. Just making the last of some charitable donations.. How about you, almost done?

question: Yep. Got it all figured out.
answer: Well, let's do it. By the way, where exactly are we going?

question: The Petrified Forest.
answer: The Petrified Forest.

question: Right. And I'm driving.
answer: Scoot over, you.

question: Know why they call it the Petrified Forest?
answer: No. Why?
